image.altText: A composite image of three people with parliament house superimposed on the backdrop

props.synopsis: In amidst the courtroom mud-slinging stand two women, both scarred by their experiences in the aftermath of an event that happened more than five years ago, and each blaming the other.

title.children: 'Catty' fashion slurs reveal the Higgins Reynolds defamation battle is taking a highly personal turn

image.altText: Casuarina Prison drone

props.synopsis: Every state and territory apart from WA runs youth justice separately from adult prisons. Keane Bourke explains why the experts say WA needs to urgently follow their lead.

title.children: WA's uniqueness is normally for the best, but in the area of youth justice it's a serious shortcoming

image.altText: Alysha Newman

props.synopsis: As critics hit out at what they believe is a broken financial model, some athletes — including Paris medal winners — are turning to OnlyFans to keep the money coming in.

title.children: 'Akin to modern-day slavery': With Olympic funding in a dire situation, athletes are turning to OnlyFans to fund their dreams

image.altText: Anthony Albanese (left) stands and shakes hands with Joe Biden in front of US and Australian flags.

props.synopsis: The idea that Australia may have signed up for "political commitments" such as accepting nuclear waste, but we aren't allowed to know, is simply outrageous.

title.children: The outrageous AUKUS secrets still being kept from Australians

image.altText: An auction sign in front of a house

props.synopsis: Despite the practice being against the law, new figures from Fair Trading NSW obtained by ABC News, shows reports of underquoting are on the rise.

title.children: A Sydney house sold for $600k above the price guide. It's just one example of a big problem

image.altText: A picture of the Boeing 737 and Donald Henderson.

props.synopsis: When the water-bomber crashed during firefighting efforts in the Fitzgerald River National Park, enthusiasts from surrounding areas scrambled for a piece of the wreckage.

title.children: How a community united to salvage the first Boeing 737 to crash on Australian soil

image.altText: Raygun

props.synopsis: Australia's first breaker, Raygun, bows out of the Paris Olympics with a performance she described as "different and creative".

title.children: In an Olympic sport that may be one and done, Australia's first breaker bows out in 'different' performance

image.altText: Mikael Wolfe with distinctive tattoos.

props.synopsis: The salesman promised to "make men huge" and send their "sex drive through the roof". Then he disappeared with their money.

title.children: ‘Gob-smacked’: An army of ripped off men found this testosterone peddler was not who he seemed

image.altText: A group of police officers stand guard at gated community

props.synopsis: Speaking at a press conference shortly after the crash, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva asked for a minute of silence for the victims.

title.children: Plane crash in Brazil kills all 61 people on board, local officials say

image.altText: A building on fire

props.synopsis: Fighting in the Kursk region of Russia continues and video shared by Ukranian media show troops in control of a Russian town.

title.children: Russia reinforces Kursk region as video shows evidence of Ukrainian 'invasion'

image.altText: Arisa Trew stands with an Australian flag over her shoulders, with PARIS 2024 visible on the skate bowl behind her.

props.synopsis: We pride ourselves on being a nation of sports lovers with active, involved kids —  but the stats tell us a different story about the opportunities for most Australian children.

title.children: Australia prides itself on being a nation of 'sport lovers', but stats reveal a complicated truth

image.altText: Bat - Wikimedia

props.synopsis: The screeching of flying mammals has been driving some diplomats batty. But after years of reaching for ear plugs and complaint forms, a good night's sleep may have finally arrived.

title.children: 'It was a lot': Noisy bats send Aussie diplomats flying

image.altText: qhuits

props.synopsis: Australian breaker Raygun makes a splash across the internet for her "different" performance as a DJ manages to settle things down in a heated beach volleyball final. Here are today's quick hits.

title.children: Olympic quick hits: Aussie breaker goes viral, US men stuff up their relay, and DJ's cheeky song choice calms down heated volleyballers

image.altText: An old photograph and sketch of a man in a photo collage

props.synopsis: The US ambassador to Mexico has confirmed that Ismael "El Mayo" Zambada did not willingly travel to Texas with the son of "El Chapo".

title.children: Mexican drug lord El Mayo brought to US against his will with El Chapo's son

image.altText: Young couple Erin and Jack stand in their living room near a window

props.synopsis: Rapidly growing house prices and sluggish wage growth means many young people have given up on the idea of ever becoming home owners, with Erin and Jack saying they've "got no hope" for a place of their own.

title.children: Priced out of home ownership, could an entire generation be stuck renting forever?

image.altText: Sunita Williams and Butch WIlmore

props.synopsis: An eight-day planned mission to the International Space Station could turn into eight months for two US astronauts, who have been unable to return home on Boeing's Starliner capsule since June. Here's what we know.

title.children: Two US astronauts could remain stuck on the International Space Station until next year, NASA admits

image.altText: A police officer attempts to control a dog, which is biting a man as a crowd looks on

props.synopsis: British authorities are grappling with the country's worst civil unrest in more than a decade, and experts say rumours disseminated by "superspreader" social media accounts are whipping "far-right thugs" and "marauding mobs" into a violent frenzy.

title.children: 'It was really a tinderbox': How disinformation is fuelling Britain's far-right riots

image.altText: A mural graffiti shows a cartoonish monkey head with its mouth open in shock.

props.synopsis: Thousands of long-tail macaques are following increasingly aggressive ringleaders into attacks on tourists and schoolkids, and now they're wising up to the "Anti-Monkey Unit's" tactics, leaving the town no choice but to try and round them up before they storm another police station.

title.children: Rival monkey gangs terrorise Thai city, mugging and assaulting schoolkids and tourists

image.altText: Man on stage singing directly into the camera

props.synopsis: A federal parliament inquiry into the state of the live music industry has characterised the fight to keep Australia's sound as "McDonald's versus the mum-and-dad burger shop". Can it be saved?

title.children: The fight happening backstage of the Australian music industry

image.altText: Blake Lively smiles and looks to the left, with flowers seen on the left and the title "It Ends With Us" on the right.

props.synopsis: It Ends With Us was the US's highest-selling book of 2023, and has just been adapted into a movie starring Blake Lively. We explain the controversy surrounding the book, which was originally released in 2016.

title.children: The It Ends With Us movie adaptation is here. Here's why people hate the Colleen Hoover novel so much

image.altText: Matt Damon and Casey Affleck sit in the front two seats of a car.

props.synopsis: The Instigators is Apple TV+'s latest attempt at reverse-engineering the kind of late-night TV movie best enjoyed by your dad.

title.children: Matt Damon and Casey Affleck bungle the basics of a heist movie in The Instigators

image.altText: Shane walks along carrying documents and wearing sunglasses.

props.synopsis: Former ACT director of public prosecutions Shane Drumgold requested the "adverse findings" made against him by inquiry head Walter Sofronoff be redacted from the report after a review found they were affected by an apprehension of bias.

title.children: Former ACT top prosecutor's bid to have some of Bruce Lehrmann inquiry report redacted rejected by government

image.altText: Tom Cruise, beyonce and Snoop Dogg are rumoured to be on the list of performers for the Paris 2024 Olympic Closing Ceremony.

props.synopsis: The Olympic closing ceremony is days away. Here's what you need to know about the line-up and how to watch.

title.children: Who's performing at the Paris 2024 Olympic closing ceremony? Here are some theories

image.altText: A split image shows Andrew Forrest smiling and Gina Rinehart in red hat

props.synopsis: Gina Rinehart and Andrew Forrest are billionaires who made their fortunes in mining. Now, the long-time rivals are going toe-to-toe in apparel, buying up some of Australia's most iconic brands. But this foray into fashion is about more than boots.

title.children: 'It's a way of buying influence': The billionaires acquiring Australia's most iconic brands

image.altText: Women run in a pack

props.synopsis: The Paris Olympic marathon is not only the conclusion of the athletics events at the Games, but the end result of decades of struggle for female athletes for recognition.

title.children: The myth and legend of the marathon as women get their moment in the sun at the Paris Olympics

image.altText: Three female runners sprint down a blue track.

props.synopsis: Unlike Eric Moussambani's celebrated swim at the Sydney Olympics, a Solomon Islands marathon runner's selection for the Paris 100m sprint has drawn anger and raised questions back home.

title.children: It was the Paris Olympics' 'Eric the Eel' moment – but with this one, people are furious

image.altText: A slice of cinnamon sugar cake on a plate with the larger cake in the background. It's topped with icing and cut doughnuts.

props.synopsis: Ella Rossanis's simple cinnamon sugar cake comes together in one bowl. Make it more indulgent with optional — but highly recommended — cream cheese icing.

title.children: A one-bowl cinnamon sugar cake inspired by doughnuts

image.altText: Imane Khelif

props.synopsis: After ugly speculation that followed Imane Khelif around the Paris Olympics, the Algerian puts it all behind her to claim gold.

title.children: After a Paris Olympics marred by speculation about her gender, Imane Khelif claims gold for Algeria

image.altText: A group of three Olympic medals - with silver, gold and bronze left to right - are shown against a dark background.

props.synopsis: Keep up with how many medals Aussie athletes have won today — and where Australia sits on the leaderboard.

title.children: Here's the medal standings after day 14 of the Olympic Games

image.altText: Naomi stands in front of a bar lined with wine glasses and wine bottles

props.synopsis: Hospitality workers say they are fed up with the ambiguity around the practice of tipping in the shift towards a cashless economy.

title.children: EFTPOS might be more convenient but it's costing cafe, restaurant staff crucial income

image.altText: Runners1

props.synopsis: Maureen Caird and Pam Kilborn were two of the greatest hurdlers in the world when the faced off at the Mexico City Olympics — and what happened would go down in Australian sporting folklore.

title.children: 'The gold medal's the only thing that counts': The rivalry between two Aussie hurdlers that created one of our great Olympics moments

image.altText: A stream of campers heading into a camp ground.

props.synopsis: What's it like when hundreds — sometimes thousands — of hunters, 4WD enthusiasts, campers and dirt-bike riders pull into a remote town in the Victorian High Country for the weekend?

title.children: The tiny Victorian town where it's almost impossible to find a parking spot at the weekend

image.altText: A high-angle of a rhythmic gymnast.

props.synopsis: A closer look at the spectacular moments of the 2024 Paris Olympic Games.

title.children: Tears, triumphs and teamwork: Paris Olympics week two captured in photos
